page.title: .addFront() - Minified.js
page.main:
back to Overview

.addFront()

Adds the given node(s) as content to the list elements as additional nodes.

Syntax

MINI(selector).addFront(text)
MINI(selector).addFront(factoryFunction)
MINI(selector).addFront(list)
MINI(selector).addFront(node)

Parameters

text
a string to add as text node of the list elements
factoryFunction
a function(listItem, listIndex) that will be invoked for each list element to create the nodes. The function can return either a string for a text node, a function to invoke, an HTML element or a list containing strings, lists, functions and/or DOM nodes.
list
a list containing text, functions, nodes or more list. Please note that if you have DOM nodes in this list and attempt to add them to more than one element, the result is undefined. You should always use factories if your MINI list contains more than one item.
node
a DOM node to add only to the first element of the list.
return value
the current list

Description

Adds the given node(s) as content to the list elements as additional nodes. Unlike add(), the new nodes will be the first children of the list items. If a string has been given, it will be added as text node. If you pass a function, it will be invoked to create node(s) with the arguments function(parent, index). It can return all values allowed by addFront(), including another function to be called. If you pass a list or a function returns a list, all its elements will be added using the rules above. It is also possible to pass a DOM node, but it will be added only to the first element of the list, because DOM does not allow adding it more than once.

Example

Using the following HTML: 
<div id="comments">Here is some text.<br/></div>
Add a text to the given 'comment' div: 
$('#comments').addFront('Some additional text. ');
This results in: 
<div id="comments">Some additional text.Here is some text.<br/></div>

Example

Using the following HTML: 
<ul id="myList">
  <li>First list entry</li>
  <li>Second list entry</li>
</ul>
The following Javascript adds an element to the list: 
$('#myList').addFront(EE('li', 'My extra point'));
This results in 
<ul id="myList">
  <li>My extra point</li>
  <li>First list entry</li>
  <li>Second list entry</li>
</ul>

Example

Use a list to add several elements at once: 
$('#comments').addFront([EE('br'), 'Some text', EE('span', {'className': 'highlight'}, 'Some highlighted text')]);

back to Overview
